awd_titl_txt: Program to integrate mobile, hands-on experiments into the ME, AE, and ECE curricula
awd_abstract_narration:
Well designed, laboratory experiences can make engineering concepts come to life, giving students a real-world confirmation of concepts and theory from lectures. However, students rarely have enough time in traditional labs to complete the tasks assigned along with pre- and post-lab exercises. Mobile hands-on learning would remove these restrictions and allow students to do experiments in their own time at any location with the help of web-based resources. The goal of this project is to develop portable hands-on engineering lab experiments for use by students outside of traditional engineering laboratories in classrooms or dorm rooms. Based on previous experiences in electrical and computer engineering, the PIs plan to deploy the portable labs across the curricula in mechanical and aerospace engineering.

The intellectual merit of the project is to develop and validate low-cost, highly-flexible, mobile, hands-on experimental platforms in mechanical and aerospace engineering. Technological innovations that enable this paradigm shift in lab instruction include new data acquisition devices, powerful micro-controllers and low cost sensors. The portable hands-on experimental modules to be developed will feature moving parts, fluidic and thermal components that are typically found in mechanical and aerospace engineering systems. It is expected that a new pedagogical model that promotes a more complete integration of theory and practice will be created, one that will open new avenues for inquiry-based learning. Several research questions will be addressed pertaining to the impact of the new modules on student learning, student interest, and on long-term retention of knowledge. Specific studies will be done to examine the impact of the developed modules on students from underrepresented groups and to seek instructor intervention methods that improve that impact. The role of online discussion forums as a support mechanism for mobile hands-on learning will also be examined.  The broader impact of this project includes giving students the ability to perform experiments at their own pace anywhere/anytime while providing educators with innovative and flexible educational technology. Partnering with Georgia Tech are Howard University, Southern Polytechnic State University, National Instruments, Piazza, and Texas Instruments all of whom will work to ensure the validity of the methods developed and ensure their dissemination to a broad audience.

por.por_cntn:
Experiential learning can be very effective in getting students to interact with engineering concepts and see them in action shortly before or after being exposed to the theory. Team-based activities that accompany hands-on learning are a further way of enhancing learning as students collaborate with each other to discuss and test their ideas. This project aimed to amplify such hands-on experiences by developing new mobile experimental platforms in mechanics, thermal systems, and electrical/electronic systems for use in core and multidisciplinary courses.  The project was also concerned with effective instruction and classroom practices to ensure that diverse student teams function well, with all students feeling comfortable and confident to work together to learn new concepts. 

Early accomplishments of this research project were built off successes at Georgia Tech in hands-on learning platforms used in the areas of electric circuits and electronics. Motivated by the learning gains seen in electrical circuits classes, several inexpensive and portable devices were developed targeting concepts in mechanical and aerospace engineering.

A bending-beam apparatus was developed that allowed for the acquisition of strain, displacement, and rotation measurements using laptops and data-acquisition devices. All instrumentation was custom made and designed to be very simple to understand and provide good accuracy. Displacement measurements and rotations were made in 2D using inexpensive webcams while twisting was measured using inexpensive micro-electromechanical 3-axis inertial accelerometers. All measurements were made using either MATLAB or Python scripts on laptops connected to either NI myDAQs, LabJack T7-Pros or webcams. The platform can support a wide range of activities such as prescribing loads using weight sets or prescribing displacements using calibrated thumbscrews. Basic experiments involved measuring bending strains in solid section beams, while more advanced experiments involved measuring the cross-section shear-center in thin-walled beams and measuring the cross-axis deflection ratio in thin-wall beams with unsymmetrical sections. A series of procedures also were developed to allow an experiment to be carried out in a classroom setting during a lecture period. Assessments were performed to show the positive effects that the hands-on activities had on students' understanding of mechanics concepts. The platform has been used in foundational Strength of Materials classes and in an advanced class in Aerospace Structural Analysis. The experiments are being integrated into the Aerospace Engineering curriculum through laboratory courses as well as open-ended project courses. Extensive documentation of these experiments, including guidelines for making specimens using 3D printing, skeleton assignments, sample project reports, help documents, instructor notes, and annotated listings of all MATLAB and Python software, are available on request.

Other experimental platforms that were developed included a two-degree-of-freedom vibrations experiment, and a portable four-bar mechanism that showed the rudiments of mechanism design. Work carried out at Howard University focused on hands-on learning to support the study of thermal systems; in particular, portable units that could be used to study steady-state or transient heat conduction were developed.

The success of the hands-on modules in this project inspired the School of Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) and the Library at Georgia Tech to partner to institutionalize the ECE hands-on learning modules in an affordable and sustainable manner.  ECE bought the electronic boards and kits that the Library lends out as a course resource for students, similar to the traditional textbook loans. The Library estimates that they saved students over $140k this past year with this lending plan.
